subject: Re: [junit] Request features
msgSnippet: ... Actually, I meant invoking System.exit() from within the test at the point where the fatal failure occurs. @Test public void ifIFailThenStopThePresses()
messageBody:
Jeff Langr wrote:
>
>
> J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> > This goes against the basic design of JUnit, which promotes test
> > isolation. The only thing I can think of to achieve this is
> System.exit().
>
> Which is something I had to deal with two days ago, while writing tests
> against a main method. System.exit(), unfortunately, has to be
> "extracted and overridden." Unless you know of another way.

Actually, I meant invoking System.exit() from within the test at the
point where the "fatal failure" occurs.

@Test public void ifIFailThenStopThePresses() throws Exception {
try {
// body of test
}
catch (Exception die) {
die.printStackTrace();
System.exit(-1);
}
catch (AssertionError die) {
die.printStackTrace();
System.exit(-1);
}
}
